In fact, as the relationship develops in a compatible manner, these hallmarks of resistance seem to diminish by about day 21 after colonization.<ref name="two" /> Thus, there must be some sort of defense response suppression by the EcM fungi, though details concerning its nature and mechanisms have yet to be determined.
This is well illustrated by the [[monosaccharide]] uptake system in ''[[Amanita muscaria]]''. Carbon uptake requires a [[membrane transport protein|transporter]], AmMST1, that is only expressed when the fungus is cultured at low [[glucose]] levels in multiple mycorrhizal associations. This expression, and increased import of monosaccharides by the fungus, is met with an increase in the supply of [[photoassimilate]]s from the plant host. In the reverse direction, [[phosphoenolpyruvate carboxylase]] (PEPC) moderates the assimilation of [[ammonium]] and the transport of [[amino acids]] from fungus to plant.<ref name="thirtyone" /><ref name="thirtyfour" />
=== Nutrient uptake and exchange === Nitrogen is a crucial component of [[phytochemistry|plant biochemistry]], being involved in such integral compounds as [[chlorophyll]], [[enzymes]] and [[amino acids]]. However, in a vast majority of terrestrial ecosystems it is a limiting nutrient, and readily available nitrogen is in short supply compared to the recalcitrant organic forms that are often shielded from rapid breakdown. Thus, the formation of ectomycorrhizal associations offers an extremely beneficial solution by allowing for the greater exploratory capacity of fungal hyphae, as well as the more efficient acquisition of nitrogen from reserves contained in the [[soil horizon|organic horizon]].<ref name="fourteen" /><ref name="thirtyfive">{{cite journal | last1=Chalot | first1=Michel | last2=Brun | first2=Annick | year=1998 | title=Physiology of organic nitrogen acquisition by ectomycorrhizal fungi and ectomycorrhizas | journal=FEMS Microbiology Reviews | volume=22 | issue=1| pages=21–44 | doi=10.1111/j.1574-6976.1998.tb00359.x| pmid=9640645 }}</ref>
There is evidence that shows that [[glutamine]] is transferred across the root interface, following the assimilation of [[ammonium]] by the fungus. However, the pathways responsible for this conversion are largely unknown, though there are several plausible hypotheses.<ref name="thirtysix">{{cite journal | last1=Smith | first1=S. E. | last2=Smith | first2=F. A. | year=1990 | title=Tansley review No. 20. structure and function of the interfaces in biotrophic symbioses as they relate to nutrient transport | url=https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/2557209?uid=3739664&uid=2&uid=4&uid=3739256&sid=21102330312237 | journal=New Phytologist | volume=114 | issue=| pages=1–38 | doi=10.1111/j.1469-8137.1990.tb00370.x }}</ref> It is also important to note that the net transfer of nutrients to plants requires three transport components: 1) the soil-fungus interface, 2) the fungus-[[apoplast]] interface, and 3) the apoplast-root cell interface.<ref name="thirtyfive" />
As the hyphae of the Hartig net region become more densely packed, they press against the cell walls of the phytobiont’s root cells. Often the fungal and plant cell walls become almost indistinguishable where they meet, thus forming a homogenous interfacial matrix through which nutrients can easily disperse.<ref name="thirtyseven">{{cite journal | last1=Smith | first1=S. E. | display-authors=etal | year=1994 | title=Nutrient transport in mycorrhizas: structure, physiology and consequences for efficiency of the symbiosis | url=http://plantscience.psu.edu/research/labs/koide/publications/1994/nutrient-transport-mycorrhizas-structure.pdf | journal=Plant and Soil | volume=159 | issue=1| pages=103–113 | jstor=42939411 | doi=10.1007/BF00000099}}</ref> The tips of the branched hyphae contain dense [[cytoplasm]] with a high concentration of [[mitochondria]] and [[endoplasmic reticulum#Rough Endoplasmic Reticulum|rough endoplasmic reticulum]]. This arrangement is stretched in the direction of hyphal growth indicating that the transfer of nutrients between fungus and plant is localized in this area of contact.<ref name="thirtyeight">{{cite journal | last1=Kottke | first1=I. | last2=Oberwinkler | first2=F. | year=1987 | title=The cellular structure of the Hartig net: coenocytic and transfer cell‐like organization | journal=Nordic Journal of Botany | volume=7 | issue=1| pages=85–95 | doi=10.1111/j.1756-1051.1987.tb00919.x}}</ref> [[ATPase]] activity in both fungal and plant [[cell membrane|plasma membranes]] at the Hartig net indicate a cooperatively bidirectional nutrient exchange.<ref name="thirtyseven" />
[[File:Ectomycorrhizae002.jpg|thumbnail|right|Ectomycorrhiza with Douglas-fir (''[[Pseudotsuga menziesii]]'') and ''[[Cortinarius]]'' spp.]]
Due to a lack of [[septum#In mycology|septate hyphae]], a [[coenocytic]], [[transfer cell]]-like structure characterizes the Hartig net of many ectomycorrhizas, which facilitates interhyphal transport.<ref name="thirtyfive" /> Wall ingrowths in ''[[Pisonia]]'', for example, resemble those found in other plant species where [[transfer cells]] yield high rates of nutrient transport between [[apoplast]] and [[symplast]].<ref name="thirtyfive" /> Overall, ectomycorrhizal fungi receive approximately 15% of the net [[primary production]] and can provide up to 86% of a host’s nitrogen needs.<ref name="twentysix" /> Carbon allocation has been shown to be correlated with growth rates and nutrient availability. Belowground allocation is highest when nutrient availability is low and when growth rates are reduced.<ref name="thirtynine">{{cite journal | last1=Hobbie | first1=Erik A | year=2006 | title=Carbon allocation to ectomycorrhizal fungi correlates with belowground allocation in culture studies | url=http://www.cnr.berkeley.edu/brunslab/mycorrhizal/papers/hobbie2006.pdf | journal=Ecology | volume=87 | issue=3| pages=563–569 | doi=10.1890/05-0755| citeseerx=10.1.1.501.9516 }}</ref> [[Phosphorus]] is another typically limiting nutrient in many terrestrial ecosystems. Evidence suggests that phosphorus is transferred largely as inorganic [[phosphate|orthophosphate]].<ref name="thirtyseven" /> Some mat-forming ectomycorrhizas contain [[ribonucleases]] capable of rapidly [[hydrolysis|hydrolyzing]] DNA in order to obtain phosphorus from [[cell nucleus|nuclei]].<ref name="thirtyfive" />
Some studies have shown that nitrogen [[eutrophication]] decreases the amount of carbon allocation to soil biota over longer periods of time.<ref name="forty">{{cite journal | last1=Högberg | first1=Mona N. | display-authors=etal | year=2010 | title=Quantification of effects of season and nitrogen supply on tree below‐ground carbon transfer to ectomycorrhizal fungi and other soil organisms in a boreal pine forest | journal=New Phytologist | volume=187 | issue=2| pages=485–493 | doi=10.1111/j.1469-8137.2010.03274.x | pmid=20456043}}</ref><ref name="fortyone">{{cite journal | last1=Wallander | first1=H. | last2=Ekblad | first2=Alf | last3=Bergh | first3=J. | year=2011 | title=Growth and carbon sequestration by ectomycorrhizal fungi in intensively fertilized Norway spruce forests | url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0378112711003318 | journal=Forest Ecology and Management | volume=262 | issue=6| pages=999–1007 | doi=10.1016/j.foreco.2011.05.035}}</ref> This can pose problems to the mycobionts, whose production of sporocarps later in the growing season is totally dependent upon the allocation of [[photosynthate]]s from host plants.<ref name="forty" /> Unlike the major [[community (ecology)|community]] shifts that can occur in sporocarp responses to nitrogen addition, root tips and soil hyphae respond in a considerably subtler manner in the short term. However, over longer periods of time, [[eutrophication]] can cause major shifts in the dominant fungi and dramatically alter belowground diversity.<ref name="fortytwo">{{cite journal | last1=Lilleskov | first1=E. A. | last2=Hobbie | first2=E. A. | last3=Horton | first3=T. R. | year=2011 | title=Conservation of ectomycorrhizal fungi: exploring the linkages between functional and taxonomic responses to anthropogenic N deposition | url=http://www.nrs.fs.fed.us/pubs/jrnl/2011/nrs_2011_lilleskov_001.pdf | journal=Fungal Ecology | volume=4 | issue=2| pages=174–183 | doi=10.1016/j.funeco.2010.09.008}}</ref>
=== Non-nutritional benefits === Extraradical hyphae, and rhizomorphs in particular, also offer invaluable transport of water in many species. Often these develop into specialized runner hyphae and rhizomorphs capable of extending quite far from the host roots, thereby increasing the functional water access area.<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Duddridge | first1=JA | last2=Malibari | first2=A | last3=Read | first3=DJ | year=1980 | title=Structure and function of mycorrhizal rhizomorphs with special reference to their role in water transport | journal=Nature | volume=287 | issue=5785| pages=834–836 | doi=10.1038/287834a0| bibcode=1980Natur.287..834D }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Brownlee |first1=C. |last2=Duddridge |first2=J. A. |last3=Malibari |first3=A. |last4=Read|first4=D. J. |title=The structure and function of mycelial systems of ectomycorrhizal roots with special reference to their role in forming inter-plant connections and providing pathways for assimilate and water transport |journal=Plant and Soil |volume=71 |issue=1–3 |year=1983 |pages=433–443 |doi=10.1007/BF02182684}}</ref> The hyphal sheath enveloping the root tips also acts as a physical barrier shielding plant tissues from pathogens and predators. Furthermore, there has been evidence suggesting that secondary metabolites of fungal partners are capable of acting as biochemical defense mechanisms against pathogenic fungi, nematodes and bacteria that may try to infect the mycorrhizal root.<ref name="fourteen" /><ref name="Schrey-et-al-2012">{{cite journal | last1=Schrey | first1=Silvia D. | display-authors=etal | year=2012 | title=Production of fungal and bacterial growth modulating secondary metabolites is widespread among mycorrhiza-associated streptomycetes | journal=BMC Microbiology | volume=12 | issue=1| pages=164 | doi=10.1186/1471-2180-12-164| pmid=22852578 | pmc=3487804 }}</ref> Many studies also show that EcM fungi are capable of providing tolerance to soils with high concentrations of [[heavy metals]],<ref name="fortythree">{{cite journal | last1=Colpaert | first1=Jan V. | display-authors=etal | year=2011 | title=How metal-tolerant ecotypes of ectomycorrhizal fungi protect plants from heavy metal pollution | url=https://doclib.uhasselt.be/dspace/bitstream/1942/11953/1/fulltext.pdf | journal=Annals of Forest Science | volume=68 | issue=1| pages=17–24 | doi=10.1007/s13595-010-0003-9}}</ref><ref name="fortyfour">{{cite journal | last1=Blaudez | first1=Damien | last2=Botton | first2=Bernard | last3=Chalot | first3=Michel | year=2000 | title=Cadmium uptake and subcellular compartmentation in the ectomycorrhizal fungus Paxillus involutus | url=http://mic.sgmjournals.org/content/146/5/1109.long | journal=Microbiology | volume=146 | issue=5| pages=1109–1117 | doi=10.1099/00221287-146-5-1109 | pmid=10832638}}</ref><ref name="fortyfive">{{cite journal | last1=Sell | first1=Joachim | display-authors=etal | year=2005 | title=Contribution of ectomycorrhizal fungi to cadmium uptake of poplars and willows from a heavily polluted soil | journal=Plant and Soil | volume=277 | issue=1–2| pages=245–253 | doi=10.1007/s11104-005-7084-5 }}</ref> [[soil salinity|salts]],<ref name="fortysix">{{cite journal | last1=Bandou | first1=E. | display-authors=etal | year=2006 | title=The ectomycorrhizal fungus Scleroderma bermudense alleviates salt stress in seagrape (Coccoloba uvifera L.) seedlings | journal=Mycorrhiza | volume=16 | issue=8| pages=559–565 | doi=10.1007/s00572-006-0073-6 | pmid=17033816 }}</ref><ref name="fortyseven">{{cite journal | last1=Liang | first1=Y. U. | display-authors=etal | year=2007 | title=Proteome analysis of an ectomycorrhizal fungus'' Boletus edulis'' under salt shock | url=http://www.aseanbiodiversity.info/Abstract/51009637.pdf | journal=Mycological Research | volume=111 | issue=8| pages=939–946 | doi=10.1016/j.mycres.2007.06.005 | pmid=17716885}}</ref> [[radionuclides]] and [[persistent organic pollutant|organic pollutants]].<ref name="fourteen" />
=== Ectendomycorrhiza === Although EcM fungal hyphae form the [[Hartig net]] outside of root cells, penetration of plant cortical cells occasionally occurs. Many species of ectomycorrhizal fungi are capable of forming mycorrhizas with other plant species where this penetration is the normal mode of mycorrhizal formation. These associations represent a form of symbiosis intermediate to [[arbuscular mycorrhizas]] and ectomycorrhizas, termed ectendomycorrhizas. Like EcM fungi, both the mantle and Hartig net are present, though sometimes at reduced density. However, more like AM fungi, the hyphae penetrate the host’s root intracellularly. Thus, the same species of fungi can be categorized as ecto- or ectendomycorrhizas depending on the host species.<ref name="fortyeight">Quoreshi, Ali M. "The use of mycorrhizal biotechnology in restoration of disturbed ecosystem." Mycorrhizae: Sustainable Agriculture and Forestry. Springer Netherlands, 2008. 303-320. {{DOI|10.1007/978-1-4020-8770-7_13}}</ref>
== Ecology == === Biogeography and environmental gradients === Ectomycorrhizal fungi are found throughout [[taiga|boreal]], [[temperate forest|temperate]] and [[tropical forest|tropical]] ecosystems, primarily among the dominant woody-plant-producing families (3.1.a).<ref name="twentysix" /> In these more [[mesic habitat|mesic]] environments supporting [[temperate coniferous forest|coniferous]] and [[temperate broadleaf and mixed forest|mixed coniferous and deciduous forests]], the EcM produce [[proteases]] and [[acid phosphatase]] enzymes to access organic forms of both nitrogen and phosphorus.<ref name="fourteen" />
Many of the fungal families most common in temperate forests (e.g. [[Russulaceae]], [[Boletaceae]], [[Thelephoraceae]]) are also quite widespread in the [[southern hemisphere]] and tropical [[dipterocarp]] forests. While there are differences between the fungal makeup of these different ecosystems, the ectomycorrhizal fungal component shows much greater similarities than the minimal overlap that occurs between dominant plant families in temperate and tropical forests (3.5.a).<ref name="fortynine">{{cite journal | last1=Peay | first1=Kabir G. | display-authors=etal | year=2010 | title=Potential link between plant and fungal distributions in a dipterocarp rainforest: community and phylogenetic structure of tropical ectomycorrhizal fungi across a plant and soil ecotone | journal=New Phytologist | volume=185 | issue=2| pages=529–542 | doi=10.1111/j.1469-8137.2009.03075.x | pmid=19878464}}</ref>
There is evidence to suggest that communities of EcM fungi differ across soil type gradients in a tropical system. However, the particular study notes that the mechanism driving this differentiation is not clear, and the variance could be in response to the soil physiochemical environment, plant community, or both (3.5.a). Other studies offer evidence to strengthen the idea that EcM communities are indeed affected by soil environment both in the field<ref name="fifty">{{cite journal | last1=Swaty | first1=Randy L. | display-authors=etal | year=1998 | title=Temporal variation in temperature and rainfall differentially affects ectomycorrhizal colonization at two contrasting sites | url=http://www4.nau.edu/gehring/web/Publications/Swaty%20et%20al.%201998.pdf | journal=New Phytologist | volume=139 | issue=4| pages=733–739 | doi=10.1046/j.1469-8137.1998.00234.x}}</ref><ref name="fiftyone">{{cite journal | last1=Toljander | first1=Jonas F. | display-authors=etal | year=2006 | title=Species composition of an ectomycorrhizal fungal community along a local nutrient gradient in a boreal forest | journal=New Phytologist | volume=170 | issue=4| pages=873–884 | doi=10.1111/j.1469-8137.2006.01718.x | pmid=16684245}}</ref> and in the lab.<ref name="fiftytwo">{{cite journal | last1=Brearley | first1=Francis Q | year=2006 | title=Differences in the growth and ectomycorrhizal community of ''Dryobalanops lanceolata'' (Dipterocarpaceae) seedlings grown in ultramafic and non-ultramafic soils | url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0038071706002574 | journal=Soil Biology and Biochemistry | volume=38 | issue=12| pages=3407–3410 | doi=10.1016/j.soilbio.2006.05.012}}</ref><ref name="fiftythree">{{cite journal | last1=Brearley | first1=Francis Q. | display-authors=etal | year=2007 | title=How does light and phosphorus fertilisation affect the growth and ectomycorrhizal community of two contrasting dipterocarp species? | journal=Plant Ecology | volume=192 | issue=2| pages=237–249 | doi=10.1007/s11258-007-9325-6 }}</ref>
Some studies indicate that ectomycorrhizal fungi might be at odds with the general [[latitudinal gradients in species diversity|latitudinal gradient of diversity]] (LGD). Data sets, free from inconclusive fruit-body surveys and largely relying on more accurate [[sequencing]] and [[microarray]] technologies, indicate that EcM fungi may be at enhanced diversity in the [[temperate climate|temperate zone]].<ref name="twentysix" /><ref name="fiftyfour">{{cite journal | last1=Tedersoo | first1=Leho | last2=Nara | first2=Kazuhide | year=2010 | title=General latitudinal gradient of biodiversity is reversed in ectomycorrhizal fungi | journal=New Phytologist | volume=185 | issue=2| pages=351–354 | doi=10.1111/j.1469-8137.2009.03134.x | pmid=20088976}}</ref> This implies that many of the causal mechanisms proposed to explain the LGD pattern might be inapplicable, or in need of modification, in reference to EcM. Though this relationship is far from certain, there exist some hypotheses to explain the plausibility of this phenomenon: 1) EcM fungi may have evolved at higher latitudes with [[Pinaceae]] hosts, and are subsequently inferior at competition in [[tropical climates]], 2) host lineages might be more diverse in temperate conditions, and well developed soil and [[soil horizons]] in temperate regions allow for higher [[niche differentiation]] and species accumulation, and 3) tropical EcM hosts are more sparsely distributed, yielding small isolated forest islands that may reduce the population sizes and subsequent richness of EcM fungi.<ref name="fiftyfour" />
This third hypothesis is expounded on in a study demonstrating that habitat size also plays an important role in determining the [[species richness]] and assemblage structure of ectomycorrhizal fungi, namely that richness is reduced in smaller and more isolated habitat areas. The same study determined that spatial turnover of soil fungi actually occurs on scales more similar to macro-organisms.<ref name="twentysix" />
Similar to studies concerning nitrogen [[eutrophication]], EcM fungal makeup over an [[human impact on the environment|anthropogenic]] nitrogen gradient show similar trends. Species richness declined dramatically with increasing nitrogen inputs, with over 30 species represented at low nitrogen sites and only 9 at high nitrogen sites.<ref name="fiftyfive">{{cite journal | last1=Lilleskov | first1=Erik A. | display-authors=etal | year=2002 | title=Belowground ectomycorrhizal fungal community change over a nitrogen deposition gradient in Alaska | url=http://nature.berkeley.edu/brunslab/papers/lilleskov2002a.pdf | journal=Ecology | volume=83 | issue=1| pages=104–115 | doi=10.2307/2680124| jstor=2680124 }}</ref> It is speculated that as nitrogen increases, [[taxa]] shift from those specialized for low nitrogen conditions to those specialized for phosphorus uptake in low phosphorus, high nitrogen, acidified conditions.<ref name="nine" /><ref name="fiftyfive" />
=== Host specificity and community responses === Across most EcM host lineages, there appears to be low levels of [[host (biology)#Host range|specificity]], as EcM plants tend to form symbioses with many distantly related fungi.<ref name="fiftysix">Molina, Randy, Hugues Massicotte, and James M. Trappe. "Specificity phenomena in mycorrhizal symbioses: community-ecological consequences and practical implications." Mycorrhizal functioning: an integrative plant-fungal process (1992): 357-423.</ref> The benefits of this system are twofold: 1) seedlings are more likely to form mycorrhizas in a wide array of habitats, thus extending range and setting, and 2) EcM mycobionts can differ in their ability to access nutrients, thus allowing host plants better access to these minerals.<ref name="fiftyseven">{{cite journal | last1=Bruns | first1=Thomas D. | last2=Bidartondo | first2=Martin I. | last3=Taylor | first3=D. Lee | year=2002 | title=Host specificity in ectomycorrhizal communities: what do the exceptions tell us? | url=http://intl-icb.oxfordjournals.org/content/42/2/352.full | journal=Integrative and Comparative Biology | volume=42 | issue=2| pages=352–359 | doi=10.1093/icb/42.2.352 | pmid=21708728}}</ref> Many species of ''[[Alnus]]'' exhibit a very narrow range of fungal symbionts, but these fungi are not from related lineages. Thus it is the mycobionts that show phylogenetic specificity, not the [[alders]].<ref name="fiftyseven" />
A major exception to the general rule outlined above is exemplified by [[myco-heterotrophy|mycoheterotrophic]] plants that utilize ectomycorrhizas for their carbon needs. These plants, from the subfamily [[monotropaceae|Monotropoideae]], exhibit high specificity for the EcM fungi they parasitize, although different [[monotropaceae|monotrope]] species target a rather wide array of fungal lineages.<ref name="fiftyseven" />
While the plant hosts exhibit low specificity, EcM fungi exhibit various levels of specificity, and the costs and benefits to their specialization are not well understood.<ref name="fiftyeight">{{cite journal | last1=Dickie | first1=Ian A. | display-authors=etal | year=2010 | title=Co‐invasion by Pinus and its mycorrhizal fungi | journal=New Phytologist | volume=187 | issue=2| pages=475–484 | doi=10.1111/j.1469-8137.2010.03277.x | pmid=20456067}}</ref><ref name="fiftynine">{{cite journal | last1=Wolfe | first1=Benjamin E. | last2=Klironomos | first2=John N. | year=2005 | title=Breaking new ground: soil communities and exotic plant invasion | url=http://www.oeb.harvard.edu/faculty/pringle/documents/Wolfe_Klironomos_2005.pdf | journal=BioScience | volume=55 | issue=6| pages=477–487 | doi=10.1641/0006-3568(2005)055[0477:bngsca]2.0.co;2| bibcode=1985BioSc..35..499W }}</ref><ref name="sixty">{{cite journal | last1=Borowicz | first1=Victoria A. | last2=Juliano | first2=Steven A. | year=1991 | title=Specificity in host-fungus associations: Do mutualists differ from antagonists? | journal=Evolutionary Ecology | volume=5 | issue=4| pages=385–392 | doi=10.1007/BF02214155}}</ref> A good example is the suilloid group, a [[monophyletic]] assemblage containing the genera ''[[Suillus]]'', ''[[Rhizopogon]]'', ''[[Gomphidius]]'' and others. This is the largest group that exhibits such an extreme degree of specificity, with almost all of its members forming ectomycorrhizas with members of the [[Pinaceae]].<ref name="fiftyseven" /> However, many other fungal groups exhibit a very broad host-range more akin to host lineages.<ref name="sixtyone">{{cite journal | last1=Diédhiou | first1=Abdala Gamby | display-authors=etal | year=2010 | title=Multi‐host ectomycorrhizal fungi are predominant in a Guinean tropical rainforest and shared between canopy trees and seedlings | journal=Environmental Microbiology | volume=12 | issue=8| pages=2219–2232 | doi=10.1111/j.1462-2920.2010.02183.x | pmid=21966915}}</ref><ref name="sixtytwo">{{cite journal | last1=Massicotte | first1=H. B. | display-authors=etal | year=1999 | title=Diversity and host specificity of ectomycorrhizal fungi forest sites by five host species | journal=Canadian Journal of Botany | volume=77 | issue=8| pages=1053–1076 | doi=10.1139/cjb-77-8-1053}}</ref>
Host plants that are taxonomically related show more similar EcM fungal communities than do taxa that are more distantly related.<ref name="sixtythree">{{cite journal | last1=Ishida | first1=Takahide A. | last2=Nara | first2=Kazuhide | last3=Hogetsu | first3=Taizo | year=2007 | title=Host effects on ectomycorrhizal fungal communities: insight from eight host species in mixed conifer–broadleaf forests | journal=New Phytologist | volume=174 | issue=2| pages=430–440 | doi=10.1111/j.1469-8137.2007.02016.x | pmid=17388905}}</ref> [[Molecular phylogenetic]] studies have shown that fungi derived from a [[common ancestor]] are more likely to show host specificity to plants that are taxonomically related.<ref name="eleven" /><ref name="sixtyfive">{{cite journal | last1=Den Bakker | first1=Henk C. | display-authors=etal | year=2004 | title=Evolution and host specificity in the ectomycorrhizal genus Leccinum | journal=New Phytologist | volume=163 | issue=1| pages=201–215 | doi=10.1111/j.1469-8137.2004.01090.x}}</ref> Host successional status may also play a role in determining EcM fungal communities, as well as affecting the number of EcM fungal species associated with an individual host species.<ref name="sixtythree" /> Other indirect factors can also play a role in the EcM fungal community, such as leaf fall and litter quality, which subsequently affect [[calcium]] levels and [[soil pH]].<ref name="sixtysix">{{cite journal | last1=Aponte | first1=Cristina | display-authors=etal | year=2010 | title=Indirect host effect on ectomycorrhizal fungi: Leaf fall and litter quality explain changes in fungal communities on the roots of co-occurring Mediterranean oaks | url=http://dns.irnase.csic.es/users/interbos/Resultados/Publicaciones/Aponte_2010_SoilBiolandBiochem_withAppendix.pdf | journal=Soil Biology and Biochemistry | volume=42 | issue=5| pages=788–796 | doi=10.1016/j.soilbio.2010.01.014| hdl=10261/23231 }}</ref> Even establishment timeframe of the host species can have an effect, with lower EcM fungal richness associated with hosts from a [[secondary forest]] than from a [[old-growth forest|primary forest]].<ref name="sixtythree" />
The establishment of [[mycorrhizal networks|common mycelial networks]] is thought to have effects upon the plant community involved with them through their ectomycorrhizal connections. This can range from providing access to larger nutrient pools, mediating competition, and allowing resources and nutrients to be shared among individuals linked in this manner.<ref name="twenty" /><ref name="twentytwo" /><ref name="sixtyseven">{{cite journal | last1=Kennedy | first1=P. G. | last2=Izzo | first2=A. D. | last3=Bruns | first3=T. D. | year=2003 | title=There is high potential for the formation of common mycorrhizal networks between understorey and canopy trees in a mixed evergreen forest | journal=Journal of Ecology | volume=91 | issue=6| pages=1071–1080 | doi=10.1046/j.1365-2745.2003.00829.x| bibcode=2009JEcol..98...74B }}</ref>
=== Roles in invasion === [[File:Plantation SW of Loch Gynack - geograph.org.uk - 1325009.jpg|thumbnail|Pine plantation, probably inoculated with fungal spores to allow beneficial ectomycorrhizas to form]]
Mycorrhizas have been regarded as the most prevalent symbiotic condition on earth, and as such they are essential to plant nutrition in terrestrial ecosystems. Thus, even alien plants often require mycorrhizal symbionts for the establishment and spread into foreign environments. Due to the low specificity of the vast majority of [[arbuscular mycorrhizas]], AM plants often become [[invasive species|invasive]] quickly and easily, and as such, the invasions are not necessarily accompanied by a simultaneous AM fungal invasion. However, because ectomycorrhizal symbioses present a range of specificities, [[introduced species|exotic]] [[forestry]] has often relied upon the introduction of compatible EcM fungi to the foreign landscape in order to ensure the success of [[forest#Forest plantations|forest plantations]] and the like.<ref name="sixtynine">{{Cite book | last1=Díez | first1=Jesús | title=Invasion biology of Australian ectomycorrhizal fungi introduced with eucalypt plantations into the Iberian Peninsula | url=http://nature.berkeley.edu/brunslab/mycorrhizal/papers/diez2005.pdf | journal=Issues in Bioinvasion Science | volume=2005 | issue=| pages=3–15 | doi=10.1007/1-4020-3870-4_2| year=2005 | isbn=978-1-4020-2902-8 }}</ref>
This is most common in [[eucalypts]] and [[pine]]s, which are [[obligate parasite|obligate]] ectomycorrhizal trees in natural conditions.<ref name="sixtynine" /> This is evidenced by the struggle of establishment of pines in the southern hemisphere until the anthropogenic buildup of [[soil inoculant|soil inoculums]].<ref name="seventy">Richardson, David M., ed. Ecology and biogeography of Pinus. Cambridge University Press, 2000.</ref> Similarly, Australian eucalypts and [[acacias]] have evolved in isolation from the EcM fungi associated with many other temperate trees such as ''[[Pinus]]'' and ''[[Quercus]]''. Thus, much like pines in the southern hemisphere, many ''[[Eucalyptus]]'' plantations required inoculation by EcM fungi from their native landscape. In both cases, EcM networks allowed for the naturalization of the [[introduced species]], followed quickly by competition for resources with native plants and invasion into novel habitats.<ref name="sixtynine" />
Many EcM species co-invade without the help of human activity, however. Members of [[Pinaceae]] represent another prime example of this convention, often invading habitats along with specific EcM fungi from the genera ''[[Suillus]]'' and ''[[Rhizopogon]]''.<ref name="fiftyeight" /> There are, however, ectomycorrhiza-forming fungi with [[cosmopolitan distribution]]s. These EcM fungi allow non-native plant species to form mutualisms that are not novel in environments that are, thus bypassing the need for co-invasion with specific EcM fungi from the native ecosystem.<ref name="fiftyeight" />
Dominant native plants are capable of inhibition of EcM fungi on the roots of neighboring plants through the release of chemical compounds or through competitive interactions.<ref name="seventyone">{{cite journal | last1=Walker | first1=John F. | display-authors=etal | year=1999 | title=Suppression of ectomycorrhizae on canopy tree seedlings in Rhododendron maximum L. (Ericaceae) thickets in the southern Appalachians | url=http://coweeta.uga.edu/publications/1418.pdf | journal=Mycorrhiza | volume=9 | issue=1| pages=49–56 | doi=10.1007/s005720050262}}</ref> Some invasive plants are capable of inhibiting the growth of native ectomycorrhizal fungi through similar mechanisms, especially if they become established and dominant. Invasive [[garlic mustard]], ''[[Alliaria petiolata]]'', and its [[allelopathy|allelochemical]] [[benzyl]] [[isothiocyanate]] were shown to inhibit the growth of three species of EcM fungi grown on [[pinus strobus|white pine]] (''[[Pinus strobus]]'') seedlings.<ref name="seventytwo">{{cite journal | last1=Wolfe | first1=Benjamin E. | display-authors=etal | year=2008 | title=The invasive plant Alliaria petiolata (garlic mustard) inhibits ectomycorrhizal fungi in its introduced range | journal=Journal of Ecology | volume=96 | issue=4| pages=777–783 | doi=10.1111/j.1365-2745.2008.01389.x| bibcode=2009JEcol..98...74B }}</ref> Changes in EcM communities can have drastic effects on nutrient uptake and community composition of native trees, which can in turn have far-reaching ecological ramifications.<ref name="fiftynine" />
=== Competition and other plant symbionts === Competition among EcM fungi is a well-documented case of [[soil microbiology|soil microbial interactions]].<ref name="seventythree">{{cite journal | last1=Kennedy | first1=Peter G. | last2=Peay | first2=Kabir G. | last3=Bruns | first3=Thomas D. | year=2009 | title=Root tip competition among ectomycorrhizal fungi: Are priority effects a rule or an exception? | url=http://www.stanford.edu/~kpeay/papers/Kennedy,Peay,Bruns-2009-Ecology.pdf | journal=Ecology | volume=90 | issue=8| pages=2098–2107 | doi=10.1890/08-1291.1}}</ref><ref name="seventyfour">{{cite journal | last1=Kennedy | first1=Peter | year=2010 | title=Ectomycorrhizal fungi and interspecific competition: species interactions, community structure, coexistence mechanisms, and future research directions | journal=New Phytologist | volume=187 | issue=4| pages=895–910 | doi=10.1111/j.1469-8137.2010.03399.x| pmid=20673286 }}</ref><ref name="seventyfive">{{cite journal | last1=Mamoun | first1=M. | last2=Olivier | first2=J. M. | year=1993 | title=Competition between Tuber melanosporum and other ectomycorrhizal fungi under two irrigation regimes | journal=Plant and Soil | volume=149 | issue=2| pages=211–218 | doi=10.1007/BF00016611}}</ref><ref name="seventysix">{{cite journal | last1=Villeneuve | first1=Normand | last2=Le Tacon | first2=François | last3=Bouchard | first3=Daniel | year=1991 | title=Survival of inoculated Laccaria bicolor in competition with native ectomycorrhizal fungi and effects on the growth of outplanted Douglasfir seedlings | journal=Plant and Soil | volume=135 | issue=1| pages=95–107 | doi=10.1007/BF00014782}}</ref> In many experimental cases, the timing of colonization between competing EcM fungi determined which species was dominant. Namely, there was a [[priority effect]] that significantly favored the original colonists to be the most dominant, except in cases involving fungal species at a natural competitive disadvantage.<ref name="seventythree" /><ref name="seventyfour" /> This disadvantage appears to be related to the proportion of root tips colonized, and those species incapable of colonizing a sufficient proportion of host roots do not typify this priority effect.<ref name="seventythree" />
Many other [[biotic factor|biotic]] and [[abiotic factors]] can mediate competition among EcM fungi, such as temperature, [[soil pH]], [[soil moisture]], [[host (biology)#Host range|host specificity]], and competitor number.<ref name="seventyfour" /><ref name="seventyfive" /> The results of many studies concerning these factors indicate that these interactions are largely environmentally context-dependent. These aspects can often lead to “checkerboard” distribution patterns, where certain species occupy locations that are mutually exclusive of the other species.<ref name="seventyfour" />
EcM communities continue to exhibit rare EcM fungal constituents that have not been excluded, despite intense competition. Thus, mechanisms must exist that maintain diverse levels of EcM fungi.<ref name="seventyfour" /> This coexistence can be summed up in four non-mutually exclusive possibilities illustrated by Bruns: niche partitioning, disturbance-related patch dynamics, density-dependent mortality and competitive networks.<ref name="seventyseven">Bruns, Thomas D. "Thoughts on the processes that maintain local species diversity of ectomycorrhizal fungi." The significance and regulation of [[soil biodiversity]]. Springer Netherlands, 1995. 63-73. [http://nature.berkeley.edu/brunslab/papers/bruns1995.pdf PDF]</ref>
There is also some evidence for competition between EcM fungi and arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi. This is mostly noted in species, such as certain eucalypts, that are capable of hosting both EcM and AM fungi on their roots.<ref name="seventyeight">{{cite journal | last1=Chen | first1=Y. L. | last2=Brundrett | first2=M. C. | last3=Dell | first3=B. | year=2000 | title=Effects of ectomycorrhizas and vesicular–arbuscular mycorrhizas, alone or in competition, on root colonization and growth of Eucalyptus globulus and E. urophylla | journal=New Phytologist | volume=146 | issue=3| pages=545–555 | doi=10.1046/j.1469-8137.2000.00663.x }}</ref> There is also some evidence in larger scale systems, such as [[pinyon pine|pinyon]] [[pinyon-juniper woodland|woodlands]], although it is hard to extricate effects of mycorrhizal interactions (if there are any) from those of simple resource competition.<ref name="seventynine">{{cite journal | last1=McHugh | first1=Theresa A. | last2=Gehring | first2=Catherine A. | year=2006 | title=Below‐ground interactions with arbuscular mycorrhizal shrubs decrease the performance of pinyon pine and the abundance of its ectomycorrhizas | journal=New Phytologist | volume=171 | issue=1| pages=171–178 | doi=10.1111/j.1469-8137.2006.01735.x | pmid=16771992}}</ref>
Some soil [[bacteria]] have been shown to have beneficial effects upon the establishment of ectomycorrhizal symbioses.<ref name="eighty">{{cite journal | last1=Founoune | first1=Hassna | display-authors=etal | year=2002 | title=Mycorrhiza helper bacteria stimulate ectomycorrhizal symbiosis of Acacia holosericea with Pisolithus alba | journal=New Phytologist | volume=153 | issue=1| pages=81–89 | doi=10.1046/j.0028-646X.2001.00284.x }}</ref><ref name="eightyone">{{cite journal | last1=Bowen | first1=G. D. | last2=Theodorou | first2=C. | year=1979 | title=Interactions between bacteria and ectomycorrhizal fungi | url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0038071779900877 | journal=Soil Biology and Biochemistry | volume=11 | issue=2| pages=119–126 | doi=10.1016/0038-0717(79)90087-7}}</ref><ref name="eightytwo">{{cite journal | last1=Garbaye | first1=J | year=1994 | title=Tansley Review No. 76 Helper bacteria: a new dimension to the mycorrhizal symbiosis | journal=New Phytologist | volume=128 | issue=2| pages=197–210 | doi=10.1111/j.1469-8137.1994.tb04003.x }}</ref> Some of these bacteria, known as [[Mycorrhiza helper bacteria]] (MHBs), have been shown to stimulate EcM formation, root and shoot biomass. The presence of higher levels of [[ergosterol]] in the soil indicate that MHBs may be promoting fungal growth, as well, thereby generating an increase in mycelial tissue and hyphae capable of exploring greater soil volumes.<ref name="eighty" /> The mechanisms by which these bacteria stimulate mycorrhizal formation are unclear. However, some mechanistic hypotheses include the softening of cell walls to make root cells more receptive, stimulation of short root formation in plants to allow for a higher probability of encounters with fungal propagules, and mediation of chemical elicitors involved in mutual recognition.<ref name="eightytwo" /> However, regardless of mechanism, it is becoming evident that bacteria are more ubiquitous than previously thought and could represent a third component of mycorrhizas (3.4.l).<ref name="eightythree">{{cite journal | last1=Bonfante | first1=Paola | last2=Anca | first2=Iulia-Andra | year=2009 | title=Plants, mycorrhizal fungi, and bacteria: a network of interactions | url=http://www.planthealthcare.eu/files/publicaties/mycorrhizal_and_bacterial_interaction.pdf | journal=Annual Review of Microbiology | volume=63 | issue=| pages=363–383 | doi=10.1146/annurev.micro.091208.073504| pmid=19514845 }}</ref>
However, not all bacteria exhibit beneficial effects, and there exists some bacteria whose effects are quite opposite to those of MHBs, thus inhibiting ectomycorrhizal formation.<ref name="eightyone" />
=== Faunal interactions === [[File:Chanterelle.jpg|thumbnail|left|The edible epigeous fruiting body of ''[[Cantharellus cibarius]]'', the golden chanterelle]]
Many ectomycorrhizal fungi are known to rely upon [[mammals]] for the [[spore#Dispersal|dispersal of spores]], particularly those fungi with [[hypogeous]] fruiting bodies. Many species of small mammals exhibit a high degree of [[mycophagy]], ingesting a wide taxonomic range of fungi. These mammals are often drawn to hypogeous fruiting bodies because they are rich in nutrients such as nitrogen, phosphorus, minerals and vitamins. However, some sources state these nutritive properties are overstated, and it is more likely due to availability at specific times of the year, ease of harvest, and patchy nature of distribution.<ref name="twentyfive" />
The spores of these fungi are dispersed either by the actions of being unearthed and broken apart, or by ingestion and subsequent excretion. Some studies even suggest that passage through an animal's gut promotes the [[germination]] of these spores, although it is by no means necessary for a majority of fungal species.<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Claridge | first1=A. W. | display-authors=etal | year=1999 | title=Mycophagy by small mammals in the coniferous forests of North America: nutritional value of sporocarps of Rhizopogon vinicolor, a common hypogeous fungus | journal=Journal of Comparative Physiology B | volume=169 | issue=3| pages=172–178 | doi=10.1007/s003600050208}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1=Cork | first1=Steven J. | last2=Kenagy | first2=G. J. | title=Nutritional value of hypogeous fungus for a forest-dwelling ground squirrel | journal=Ecology | year=1989 | issue=3| pages=577–586 | doi=10.2307/1940209 | volume=70| jstor=1940209 }}</ref> Regardless, the ability of these certain mammals to spread fungal spores is thus indirectly related to plant community structure, by way of the pivotal role that EcM fungi play in plant nutrition and productivity.<ref name="twentyfive" />
Many other sporocarps are grazed upon by [[invertebrate]]s such as [[mollusc|mollusks]] and fly larvae, some of which are even tolerant to the toxic [[alpha-amanitin|α-amanitin]]. Belowground, populations of [[nematode]]s and [[springtail]]s are maintained by consumption of fungal tissue.<ref name="fourteen" /> There are also studies concerning EcM fungi and [[arthropod]]s. The ectomycorrhizal fungus ''[[Laccaria bicolor]]'' has been found to lure and kill [[springtail]]s to obtain nitrogen, some of which may then be transferred to the mycorrhizal host plant. In a study by Klironomos and Hart, [[eastern white pine]] inoculated with ''[[L. bicolor]]'' was able to derive up to 25% of its nitrogen from springtails.<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Klironomos | first1=John N. | last2=Hart | first2=Miranda M. | year=2001 | title=Food-web dynamics: Animal nitrogen swap for plant carbon | url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v410/n6829/abs/410651b0.html | journal=Nature | volume=410 | issue=6829| pages=651–652 | doi=10.1038/35070643 | pmid=11287942}}</ref>
Of course, edible fungus plays a role in many societies throughout the world, as well. Many [[epigeous]] [[mushroom]]s are collected and consumed on a regular basis, and more recent commercial harvesting is beginning to play a larger economic role in certain locales.<ref name="eightyfour">Arnolds, Eef. "Conservation and management of natural populations of edible fungi." Canadian Journal of Botany 73.S1 (1995): 987-998.</ref> Certainly, [[truffles]] (''[[Tuber]]''), [[porcini]]s (''[[Boletus]]'') and [[chanterelles]] (''[[Cantharellus]]'') are commonly known for their taste and culinary importance, as well as their billion dollar worldwide market.<ref name="eightyfive">{{cite journal | last1=Yun | first1=Wang | last2=Hall | first2=Ian R. | year=2004 | title=Edible ectomycorrhizal mushrooms: challenges and achievements | url=http://chaireafd.uqat.ca/evenement/pdf/fortin%20-%20(02).pdf | journal=Canadian Journal of Botany | volume=82 | issue=8| pages=1063–1073 | doi=10.1139/b04-051}}</ref>
== Plant production == === Agriculture === Ectomycorrhizal fungi do not play a large role in [[agricultural]] and [[horticultural]] systems. Most of the economically relevant [[crop]] plants that form mycorrhizas tend to form them with arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi.<ref name="eightysix">{{cite journal | last1=Munyanziza | first1=E. | last2=Kehri | first2=H. K. | last3=Bagyaraj | first3=D. J. | year=1997 | title=Agricultural intensification, soil biodiversity and agro-ecosystem function in the tropics: the role of mycorrhiza in crops and trees | url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0929139396001527 | journal=Applied Soil Ecology | volume=6 | issue=1| pages=77–85 | doi=10.1016/S0929-1393(96)00152-7}}</ref> Many modern agricultural practices such as [[tillage]], heavy [[fertilizers]], and [[fungicides]] have extremely detrimental effects on crops’ associated mycorrhizas and on the surrounding ecosystem. Thus, it is possible that agriculture indirectly affects nearby ectomycorrhizal species and habitats, such as increased fertilization decreasing sporocarp production.<ref name="eightyseven">Amaranthus, Michael P. The importance and conservation of ectomycorrhizal fungal diversity in forest ecosystems: lessons from Europe and the Pacific Northwest. US Department of Agriculture, Forest Service, Pacific Northwest Research Station, 1998. [http://ephraimrisho.com/fungaljungal.org/papers/Amaranthus_fungal_import.pdf]</ref><ref name="eightyeight">{{cite journal | last1=Grant | first1=Cynthia | display-authors=etal | year=2005 | title=Soil and fertilizer phosphorus: Effects on plant P supply and mycorrhizal development | url=http://www.cfr.washington.edu/classes.esrm.410/ESRM%20410%202011/Lectures/Lect09%20Literature/Phosphorus%20and%20Mycorrhizae_Grant_2005.pdf | journal=Canadian Journal of Plant Science | volume=85 | issue=1| pages=3–14 | doi=10.4141/p03-182}}</ref>
=== Forestry === In commercial [[forestry]], the [[transplanting]] of crop trees in new locales often requires an accompanying ectomycorrhizal partner. This is especially true of trees that have a high degree of specificity for their mycobiont, or trees that are being planted far from their native habitat among novel fungal species. This has been shown time and again in [[plantations]] involving obligate ectomycorrhizal trees, such as ''[[Eucalyptus]]'' and ''[[Pinus]]'' species.<ref name="sixtynine" /> Mass planting of these species often require human addition of inoculum from native EcM fungi in order for the trees to prosper.
Thus, these EcM fungi have to be species that are capable of being grown in bulk. After being added to various soil mixtures, the mutualism can begin as seedlings are grown in [[plant nursery|nurseries]] or plantations. This is already becoming quite commonplace, and there are many companies that are beginning to sell a variety of mycorrhizal inoculum, ''[[Pisolithus tinctorius]]'' being quite widespread among the EcM fungi.<ref name="eightyseven" />
Sometimes ectomycorrhizal plantation species, such as [[pine]] and [[eucalyptus]], are planted and promoted for their ability to act as a [[carbon sink|sink]] for atmospheric carbon. However, the ectomycorrhizal fungi of these species also tend to deplete soil carbon over relatively short periods of time.<ref name="eightynine">{{cite journal | last1=Scott | first1=Neal A. | display-authors=etal | year=1999 | title=Soil carbon storage in plantation forests and pastures: land‐use change implications | journal=Tellus B | volume=51 | issue=2| pages=326–335 | doi=10.1034/j.1600-0889.1999.00015.x}}</ref> Thus there is a great deal of mounting resistance to using tree plantations as general solutions to combatting rising [[carbon dioxide]] levels.<ref name="ninety">{{cite journal | last1=Chapela | first1=Ignacio H. | display-authors=etal | year=2001 | title=Ectomycorrhizal fungi introduced with exotic pine plantations induce soil carbon depletion | url=http://nature.berkeley.edu/brunslab/papers/chapela2001.pdf | journal=Soil Biology and Biochemistry | volume=33 | issue=12| pages=1733–1740 | doi=10.1016/s0038-0717(01)00098-0}}</ref>
=== Restoration === Ectomycorrhizas provide many benefits to their host plants, with enhanced nutrient uptake, growth and establishment in disturbed habitats ranked highly among them.<ref name="fortyeight" /> Thus, it seems logical that EcM fungi could be used in [[restoration ecology|restoration]] projects aimed at re-establishing native plant species in [[ecosystems]] disrupted by a variety of issues.<ref name="ninetyone">{{Cite book | last1=Kernaghan | first1=G. | display-authors=etal | year=2002 | title=In Vitro Selection of Boreal Ectomycorrhizal Fungi for Use in Reclamation of Saline‐Alkaline Habitats | url=http://faculty.msvu.ca/fungal_ecology/Publi_Pdf/In%20vitro%20selection%20of%20ectomycorrhizal%20fungi%20for%20reclamation%20of%20alkaline-saline%20habitats.pdf | journal=Restoration Ecology | volume=10 | issue=1| pages=43–51 | doi=10.1046/j.1526-100x.2002.10105.x| bibcode=1990reec.book.....J }}</ref> In addition to providing a certain degree of protection to seedlings in harsh circumstances, such as increased [[soil salinity|salinity]] or [[heavy metal (chemistry)|heavy metal]] [[pollution]], the fungi are also instrumental in improving [[soil quality]].<ref name="ninetyone" /> They are able to achieve this through allowing the establishment of early vegetation and subsequent organic litter, [[erosion#Prevention and remediation|preventing erosion]], and binding soil particles together yielding stability and soil aggregation.<ref name="fourteen" /> Since the disappearance of mycorhizal fungi from a habitat constitutes a major soil disturbance event, its re-addition is an important part of establishing vegetation and restoring habitats.<ref name="fortyeight" />
== Global change == === Heavy metals ===
[[Heavy metal (chemistry)|Heavy metals]] are well known [[Metal toxicity|toxic]] agents for living organisms. High soil concentrations of [[Heavy metal (chemistry)|heavy metals]] such as [[zinc]], [[copper]], [[cadmium]], [[lead]], [[nickel]], and [[chromium]] affect basic [[Metabolism|metabolic processes]] and can lead to [[cell damage]] and death. Ectomycorrhizal fungi are susceptible to heavy metal contamination. However, there seems to be widespread heavy metal tolerance in these fungi, with many species having the ability to colonize soils both with and without high heavy metal content. This said, there are a few examples of [[ecotype]]s associated with harsh soil chemistry,<ref name="Colpaert,2011">{{cite journal | last1=Colpaert | first1=J. | year=2011 | title=How metal-tolerant ecotypes of ectomycorrhizal fungi protect plants from heavy metal pollution | journal=Annals of Forest Science | volume=68 | issue=| pages=17–24 | doi=10.1007/s13595-010-0003-9}}</ref> indicating such inhospitable soils can lead to fungal evolutionary change.
Heavy metal excess interferes with basic cell functions, affecting the metabolism, growth, and differentiation of ectomycorrhizal fungi. High heavy metal concentrations may lead to the blocking of functional groups of important molecules such as enzymes, displacement and/or substitution of essential metals from molecules involved in cell processes, modification of molecule conformation and denaturation, as well as membrane disruption.<ref name="Gadd,1993">{{cite journal | last1=Gadd | first1=G.M. | year=1993 | title=Interaction of fungi with toxic metals | journal=New Phytologist | volume=124 | issue=| pages=25–60 | doi=10.1111/j.1469-8137.1993.tb03796.x}}</ref> The effects of high heavy metal concentrations on ectomycorrhizal fungi vary by metal and fungal species and range from high fungal sensitivity to wide fungal tolerance. Overall, ectomycorrhizal fungi show high constitutive tolerance with many species being able to survive in toxic and non-toxic environments. However, there are cases of [[Ecotype|populations locally adapted]] to tolerate harsh chemical environments <ref name="Colpaert,2011" />
Fungi exhibit [[detoxification]] mechanisms that ensure heavy metal concentrations in their cells do not exceed a certain threshold. These mechanisms include reducing heavy metal uptake, promoting heavy metal sequestration and storage within the cell, and heavy metal excretion. Heavy metal uptake can be reduced by [[sorption]] and metabolic inactivation at the cell wall and apoplast level.<ref name="Colpaert,2011" /> Ectomycorrhizal fungi also have the ability to [[Molecular binding|bind]] considerable amounts of heavy metals,<ref name="Colpaert,2011" /><ref name="Blaudez,2000">{{cite journal | last1=Blaudez | first1=D. | last2=Jacob | first2=C. | last3=Turnau | first3=K. | last4=Colpaert | first4=J.V. | last5=Ahonen-Jonnath | first5=U. | last6=Finlay | first6=R. | last7=Botton | first7=B. | last8=Chalot | first8=M. | year=2000 | title=Differential responses of ectomycorrhizal fungi to heavy metals in vitro | journal=Mycological Research | volume=104 | issue=11| pages=1366–1371 | doi=10.1017/s0953756200003166}}</ref> yet it remains unclear if binding is an effective way to prevent heavy metals to enter fungal cells. Once inside the cell, heavy metals can be immobilized in organo-metal complexes, made soluble, transformed into [[metallothionein]]s, involved in metal sequestration and/or stored in vacuoles in chemically inactive forms. [[Antioxidant]] detoxification systems may also be in place, reducing the production of [[Radical (chemistry)|free radicals]] and protecting the fungal cell.<ref name=Gadd,2004 >{{cite journal | last1=Gadd | first1=G.M. | year=2004 | title=Microorganisms and heavy metal toxicity | journal=Microbial Ecology | volume=4 | issue=4| pages=303–317 | doi=10.1007/bf02013274| pmid=24232222 }}</ref><ref name=Bellion,2006>{{cite journal | last1=Bellion | first1=M. | last2=Courbot | first2=M | last3=Jacob | first3=C. | display-authors=etal | year=2006 | title=Extracellular and cellular mechanism sustaining metal tolerance in ectomycorrhizal fungi | journal=FEMS Microbiology Letters | volume=254 | issue=2| pages=173–181 | doi=10.1111/j.1574-6968.2005.00044.x| pmid=16445743 }}</ref> Fungi can export metals from the cytoplasm to the apoplast. This differential [[efflux (microbiology)|efflux]] efficiently discards heavy metals from the cell and is also known to occur in plants.<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Lasat | first1=M.M. | last2=Baker | first2=A.J.M. | last3=Kochian | first3=L.V. | year=1998 | title=Altered Zn compartmentation in the root symplasm and stimulated Zn absorption into the leaf as mechanisms involved in Zn hyperaccumulation in ''Thlaspi caerulescens'' | journal=Plant Physiology | volume=118 | issue=3| pages=875–883 | doi=10.1104/pp.118.3.875| pmid=9808732 | pmc=34798 }}</ref> It has also been shown that ectomycorrhizal fungi growing in heavy metal rich soils often exhibit heavy metals in their sporocarps in addition to other mycelial tissue.<ref name="ninetytwo">{{cite journal | last1=Leyval | first1=C. | last2=Turnau | first2=K. | last3=Haselwandter | first3=K. | year=1997 | title=Effect of heavy metal pollution on mycorrhizal colonization and function: physiological, ecological and applied aspects | journal=Mycorrhiza | volume=7 | issue=3| pages=139–153 | doi=10.1007/s005720050174}}</ref> This binding of heavy metals to the cell wall, using components such as [[chitin]] and [[melanin]], could possibly play a role in the mechanism determining ectomycorrhizal fungi heavy metal tolerance in general.<ref name="fortyfour" />
Little is known about the environmental requirements or limitations of ectomycorrhizal fungi. However, many species are found to live in toxic and non-toxic environments and genetic differences between populations from such habitats have rarely been reported. This indicates widespread metal tolerance in these fungi. No metal-adapted [[Endemism|endemic]] taxa have been documented so far.<ref name="Blaudez,2000" /><ref>{{cite journal | last1=Southworth | first1=D. | last2=Tackleberry | first2=L.E. | last3=Massicotte | first3=H.B. | year=2013 | title=Mycorrhizal ecology on serpentine soils | journal=Plant Ecology and Diversity | volume=7 | issue=3| pages= 445–455| doi=10.1080/17550874.2013.848950 }}</ref> There is however, evidence for community shifts associated with heavy metals,<ref>Colpaert, J.V. 2008. Heavy metal pollution and genetic adaptations in ectomycorrhizal fungi. In: Avery S.V., Stratford M., Van West P. (eds) Stress in yeasts and filamentous fungi. Academic, Amsterdam, pp 157–174.</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1=Ruotsalainen | first1=A.L. | last2=Markkola | first2=A.M. | last3=Kozlov | first3=M.V. | year=2009 | title=Mycorrhizal colonisation of mountain birch (''Betula pubescens'' ssp ''czerepanovii'') along three environmental gradients: does life in harsh environments alter plant–fungal relationships? | journal=Environ Monit Assess | volume=148 | issue=1–4| pages=215–232 | doi=10.1007/s10661-007-0152-y| pmid=18327653 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1=Staudenrausch | first1=S. | last2=Kaldorf | first2=M. | last3=Renker | first3=C. | last4=Luis | first4=P. | last5=Buscot | first5=F. | year=2005 | title=Diversity of the ectomycorrhiza community at a uranium mining heap | journal=Biol Fertil Soils | volume=41 | issue=6| pages=439–446 | doi=10.1007/s00374-005-0849-4}}</ref> with lower diversity associated with contaminated sites. Soils naturally rich in heavy metals, such as [[serpentine soil]]s, on the other hand do not seem to imprint significant changes on ectomycorrhizal fungal communities.<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Branco | first1=S. | last2=Ree | first2=R. | year=2010 | title=Serpentine soils do not limit mycorrhizal fungal diversity | journal=PLOS ONE | volume=5 | issue=7| page=e11757 | doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0011757| pmid=20668696 | pmc=2909254 | bibcode=2010PLoSO...511757B }}</ref> In fact, the levels of fungal diversity in serpentine soils are comparable to those in non-serpentine soils and no serpentine [[Endemism|endemics]] have so far been reported.
[[File:Suillus luteus G4.JPG|thumb|''[[Suillus luteus]]'', an ectomycorrhizal fungus with [[ecotype]]s that are known to be associated with [[Heavy metal (chemistry)|heavy metal]] concentrations]]
Although widespread tolerance seems to be the norm for ectomycorrhizal fungi, adaptive metal tolerance has been suggested for a few fungi such as ''Pisolithus tinctorius'',<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Egerton-Warburton | first1=L. | last2=Griffin | first2=B. | year=1995 | title=Differential responses of ''Pisolithus tinctorius'' isolates to aluminium in vitro | journal=Canadian Journal of Botany | volume=73 | issue=8| pages=1229–1233 | doi=10.1139/b95-133}}</ref> ''P. albus''<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Jourand | first1=P. | last2=Ducousso | first2=M. | last3=Loulergue-Majorel | first3=C. | last4=Hannibal | first4=L. | last5=Santoni | first5=S. | last6=Prin | first6=Y. | last7=Lebrun | first7=M. | year=2010 | title=Ultramafic soils from New Caledonia structure ''Pisolithus albus'' in ecotype | journal=FEMS Microbiology Ecology | volume=72 | issue=2| pages=238–249 | doi=10.1111/j.1574-6941.2010.00843.x| pmid=20199570 }}</ref> and species in the genus ''Suillus''.<ref name="Colpaert,2000" >{{cite journal | last1=Colpaert | first1=J.V. | last2=Vandenkoornhuyse | first2=P. | last3=Adriaensen | first3=K. | last4=Vangronsveld | first4=J. | year=2000 | title=Genetic variation and heavy metal tolerance in the ectomycorrhizal basidiomycete ''Suillus luteus'' | journal=New Phytologist | volume=147 | issue=2| pages=367–379 | doi=10.1046/j.1469-8137.2000.00694.x}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1=Colpaert | first1=J.V. | last2=Muller | first2=L.A.H. | last3=Lambaerts | first3=M. | last4=Adriaensen | first4=K. | last5=Vangronsveld | first5=J. | year=2004 | title=Evolutionary adaptation to zinc toxicity in populations of ''Suilloid'' fungi | journal=New Phytologist | volume=162 | issue=2| pages=549–559 | doi=10.1111/j.1469-8137.2004.01037.x}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1=Krznaric | first1=E. | last2=Verbruggen | first2=N. | last3=Wevers | first3=J.H.L. | last4=Carleer | first4=R. | last5=Vangronsveld | first5=J. | last6=Colpaert | first6=J.V. | year=2009 | title=Cd-tolerant ''Suillus luteus'': a fungal insurance for pines exposed to Cd | journal=Environ Pollut | volume=157 | issue=5| pages=1581–1588 | doi=10.1016/j.envpol.2008.12.030 | pmid=19211178}}</ref> Fungal ecotypes specialized to high levels of heavy metals have been found to be adapted to high levels of Al, Zn, Cd and Cu. A reduced number of species is known to be adapted to different metals with different ecotypes arising recurrently.<ref name="Colpaert,2011" /> This suggests that some species are more prone to adapt to chemically inhospitable edaphic environments. ''Suillus luteus'' and ''S. bovinus'' are good examples, with known ecotypes adapted to Zn, Cd and Cu.<ref name="Colpaert,2011" /><ref name="Colpaert,2000" /><ref>{{cite journal | last1=Adriaensen | first1=K. | last2=Vrålstad | first2=T. | last3=Noben | first3=J.P. | last4=Vangronsveld | first4=J. | last5=Colpaert | first5=J.V. | year=2005 | title=Copper-adapted ''Suillus luteus'', a symbiotic solution for pines colonizing Cu mine spoils | journal=Appl Environ Microbiol | volume=71 | issue=11| pages=7279–7284 | doi=10.1128/aem.71.11.7279-7284.2005| pmid=16269769 | pmc=1287625 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1=Ruytinx | first1=J. | last2=Nguyen | first2=H. | last3=Van Hees | first3=M. | last4=De Beeck | first4=O. | last5=Vangronsveld | first5=J. | last6=Carleer | first6=R. | last7=Colpaert | first7=J.V. | last8=Adriaensen | first8=K. | year=2013 | title=Zinc export results in adaptive zinc tolerance in the ectomycorrhizal basidiomycete ''Suillus bovinus'' | journal=Metallomics | volume=5 | issue=9| pages=1225–1233 | doi=10.1039/c3mt00061c| pmid=23715468 }}</ref> These differentiated populations accumulate lower heavy metal concentrations in their [[Mycelium|mycelia]] and in a slower fashion compared to sensitive [[ecotype]]s. More specifically, the accumulation of heavy metals in the fungal tissue is prevented through a mechanism that efficiently exports metals to the outside of the cell. When compared to non-mycorrhizal fine roots, ectomycorrhizae may contain very high concentrations of trace elements, including toxic metals (cadmium, silver) or chlorine. <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Cejpková|first1=J|last2=Gryndler|first2=M|last3=Hršelová|first3=H|last4=Kotrba|first4=P|last5=Řanda|first5=Z|last6=Greňová|first6=I|last7=Borovička|first7=J|title=Bioaccumulation of heavy metals, metalloids, and chlorine in ectomycorrhizae from smelter-polluted area|journal=Environmental Pollution|volume=218|pages=176–185|doi=10.1016/j.envpol.2016.08.009|pmid=27569718|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0269749116306790?via%3Dihub|year=2016}}</ref>
=== Pollution and Phytoremediation === One type of [[pollution]] that poses considerable challenges and threats to plants is the concentration of [[heavy metals]] in the soil. Although many metals are important nutrients in small quantities, such as [[copper]], [[iron]] and [[zinc]], in high concentrations they pose a particularly devastating risk due to their toxicities.<ref name="fortythree" /> See Ectomycorrhizas and heavy metals for a description of how heavy metals affect ectomycorrhizal fungi.
Another problem faced by many plants is high [[soil salinity]]. One study shows that some EcM fungi are capable of improving salt tolerance in a species of poplar by altering leaf physiology. Though the symbiotic contact takes place at the root interface, the fungus was able to alter such leaf traits as concentration of nutrients and [[phytohormones]], and ratios of [[fatty acids]] in order to combat leaf [[chlorosis]] and shedding.<ref name="ninetythree">{{cite journal | last1=Luo | first1=Zhi-Bin | display-authors=etal | year=2011 | title=The ectomycorrhizal fungus (Paxillus involutus) modulates leaf physiology of poplar towards improved salt tolerance | url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0098847211001006 | journal=Environmental and Experimental Botany | volume=72 | issue=2| pages=304–311 | doi=10.1016/j.envexpbot.2011.04.008}}</ref> In [[coccoloba uvifera|seagrape]] seedlings, the EcM fungus ''[[Scleroderma (genus)|Scleroderma]] [[List of Scleroderma species|bermudense]]'' was able to alleviate salt stress. In the seagrape tissue, there was a decrease in both [[sodium]] and [[chlorine]], but an increase in [[potassium]] and [[phosphorus]], implying this trend might represent a mechanism to explain the observed tolerance.<ref name="fortysix" /> Another study even identified 22 proteins differentially produced under salt stress of the EcM fungus ''[[Boletus edulis]]''. They mostly concerned cellular processes such as [[metabolism]], [[cell cycle]] control and stress tolerance, with 14 proteins being [[upregulated]] and 8 down.<ref name="fortyseven" />
Many species of ectomycorrhizal fungi, most notably those from [[Cortinariaceae]], are capable of becoming [[phytoremediation#Phytoextraction|hyperaccumulators]] of [[radionuclides]]. This is similar to their ability to absorb heavy metals, though mechanisms are largely unresearched. In a study in Sweden, sporocarps of an ectomycorrhizal fungus contained ten times the concentration of [[radiocesium]] than the surrounding litter, while saprotrophic species exhibited nearly half that value.<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Nikolova | first1=Ivanka | last2=Johanson | first2=Karl J. | last3=Dahlberg | first3=Anders | year=1997 | title=Radiocaesium in fruitbodies and mycorrhizae in ectomycorrhizal fungi | url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0265931X96000380 | journal=Journal of Environmental Radioactivity | volume=37 | issue=1| pages=115–125 | doi=10.1016/S0265-931X(96)00038-0}}</ref>
Some species are capable of decomposing [[persistent organic pollutant]]s (POPs) as well, such as [[organochloride]]s and [[polychlorinated biphenyls]] (PCBs). Species such as ''[[Suillus variegatus]]'' and ''[[Paxillus involutus]]'' were able to [[mineralization (soil science)|mineralize]] [[2,4-dichlorophenol]] both in [[axenic culture]] and in an EcM association with ''[[Pinus sylvestris]]''.<ref name="rhizorem">{{cite journal | last1=Meharg | first1=Andrew A. | last2=Cairney | first2=John WG | year=2000 | title=Ectomycorrhizas—extending the capabilities of rhizosphere remediation? | url=http://elmu.umm.ac.id/file.php/1/jurnal/S/Soil%20Biology%20And%20Chemistry/Vol32.Issue11-12.oct2000/1686.pdf | journal=Soil Biology and Biochemistry | volume=32 | issue=11| pages=1475–1484 | doi=10.1016/s0038-0717(00)00076-6}}</ref> The intact rhizosphere of ''[[Pinus taeda]]'' also exhibited the capacity to mineralize [[tetrachloroethylene]] under natural conditions.<ref name="rhizorem" /> The EcM fungi ''[[Radiigera|Radiigera atrogleba]]'' and ''[[Hysterangium|Hysterangium garneri]]'' were capable of decomposing up to 80% of a particular PCB when tested.<ref name="fourteen" />
However, not every problem is alleviated by the presence of EcM fungi. There is some evidence that points to an inhibition in degrading recalcitrant pollutants such as [[polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons]]. It is thought that these fungi take away nutrients from other degraders that would be better at degrading these compounds, therefore inhibiting their actions.<ref name="ninetyfour">{{cite journal | last1=Joner | first1=Erik J. | last2=Leyval | first2=Corinne | last3=Colpaert | first3=Jan V. | year=2006 | title=Ectomycorrhizas impede phytoremediation of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) both within and beyond the rhizosphere | url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0269749105004902 | journal=Environmental Pollution | volume=142 | issue=1| pages=34–38 | doi=10.1016/j.envpol.2005.09.007| pmid=16325973 }}</ref>
=== Climate change === [[Climate change]] can induce a number of changes on the environment, and subsequently, ectomycorrhizal communities. Many of these studies are in their infancy, but it is clear that they often exhibit some effect. In some studies, elevated CO<sub>2</sub> levels increased fungal mycelium growth due to increased carbon allocation<ref name="ninetyfive">{{cite journal | last1=Fransson | first1=Petra MA | last2=Taylor | first2=Andy FS | last3=Finlay | first3=Roger D. | year=2005 | title=Mycelial production, spread and root colonisation by the ectomycorrhizal fungi Hebeloma crustuliniforme and Paxillus involutus under elevated atmospheric CO2 | journal=Mycorrhiza | volume=15 | issue=1| pages=25–31 | doi=10.1007/s00572-003-0289-7 | pmid=14750001 }}</ref> and increased EcM root colonization by 14%.<ref name="ninetysix">{{cite journal | last1=Garcia | first1=Maria O. | display-authors=etal | year=2008 | title=Mycorrhizal dynamics under elevated CO2 and nitrogen fertilization in a warm temperate forest | url=https://webfiles.uci.edu/treseder/public/Publications/Garcia_etal_2008.pdf | journal=Plant and Soil | volume=303 | issue=1–2| pages=301–310 | doi=10.1007/s11104-007-9509-9}}</ref> However, CO<sub>2</sub> levels can affect different EcM associations quite differently, and many studies with negligible effects have also been performed.<ref name="ninetyseven">{{cite journal | last1=Compant | first1=Stéphane | last2=Marcel | last3=Der Heijden | first3=GA Van | last4=Sessitsch | first4=Angela | year=2010 | title=Climate change effects on beneficial plant–microorganism interactions | journal=FEMS Microbiology Ecology | volume=73 | issue=2| pages=197–214 | doi=10.1111/j.1574-6941.2010.00900.x | pmid=20528987 }}</ref>
Increased temperatures also appear to affect EcM communities, though the results cover a range of responses. Some studies have shown that [[cellular respiration|respiration]] is reduced in certain species in response to warming,<ref name="ninetyeight">{{cite journal | last1=Malcolm | first1=Glenna M. | display-authors=etal | year=2008 | title=Acclimation to temperature and temperature sensitivity of metabolism by ectomycorrhizal fungi | journal=Global Change Biology | volume=14 | issue=5| pages=1169–1180 | doi=10.1111/j.1365-2486.2008.01555.x | bibcode=2008GCBio..14.1169M }}</ref> whereas others demonstrated increased total colonization of host plants.<ref name="fifty" /> Similarly, it appears that only some EcM species are affected by [[drought]], as there are studies yielding results across the spectrum. However, many species provide protection against root [[desiccation]] and improve water uptake ability of the roots. In this sense, they provide a general benefit to plants during times of drought (though they may themselves may be affected over time).<ref name="ninetyseven" />
Regardless of how variably these EcM symbioses may change in response to the changing environmental conditions, it is clear that they do at least change. Thus, as more research is compiled, and as patterns and general effects emerge, we will have a better understanding of the no doubt critical consequences climate change has on EcM communities.
=== Conservation === As it becomes more apparent that belowground organisms and functions heavily influence forest productivity, recovery and stability, ectomycorrhiza are becoming a prime focus for [[conservation biology|conservation]] ecologists.<ref name="eightyseven" /> The recent decline of many species of EcM fungi in [[Europe]] has also allowed the importance of EcM disappearance to gain traction in more widespread conservation circles. Many factors are contributing to the decline, including reduced tree vitality, conversion of forests to other uses, [[pollution]] and [[soil acidification|acidification of forest soils]].<ref name="eightyseven" /><ref name="ninetynine">{{cite journal | last1=Arnolds | first1=E. E. F. | year=1991 | title=Decline of ectomycorrhizal fungi in Europe | journal=Agriculture, Ecosystems & Environment | volume=35 | issue=2| pages=209–244 | doi=10.1016/0167-8809(91)90052-y}}</ref>
Conservation efforts need to be based on protecting species over their entire host range and habitat, not just at particular sites or with particular species.<ref name="eightyseven" /> Studies have shown that even in many different soil types and locations EcM fungal richness is relatively conserved, but that the community makeup of sites can still be quite different. Trees are often dominated by a few fungal strains, but these fungi are not the same on all trees in nearby areas, and show considerable spatial variation. This leads to the conclusion that conservation efforts should be aimed even at atypical sites, such as abiotically stressful locales, in order to conserve the full gamut of EcM fungal partners and plant host species.<ref name="twentyseven" />
The growing importance of EcM fungi in the field of conservation is evidenced by the creation of the [[Northwest Forest Plan]], which offers guidelines to maintain habitats and [[endangered species]]. This includes creating databases for endangered fungi and developing strategies to manage and protect them. Another example in a similar vein is the creation of the European Council for the Conservation of Fungi, which works with education about, and the documentation of, endangered fungi on the continent.<ref name="eightyseven" /> Organizations and groups like these are valuable in disseminating knowledge concerning conservation practices for scientists and the public. They also help compile solutions for fields like [[forest management]] that act to preemptively halt EcM declines.
[[File:Prescribed burn in a Pinus nigra stand in Portugal.JPG|thumbnail|right|Prescribed burn in a stand of ''Pinus nigra''. What effects could this have on the ectomycorrhizas below ground?]]
In many cases, forest managers and scientists must take steps to ensure the health of economically important native forests, such as the maintenance of: 1) refuge plants and reservoir hosts after harvesting to preserve the EcM fungal community, 2) mature trees to provide seedlings with a diverse array of EcM fungi, and 3) [[old-growth]] stands with their more diverse macro- and [[microhabitats]] that support an abundance of EcM fungi.<ref name="onehundred">Wiensczyk, Alan M., et al. "Ectomycorrhizae and forestry in British Columbia: A summary of current research and conservation strategies." ''Journal of Ecosystems and Management'' 2.1 (2002). [http://www.siferp.org/sites/default/files/publications/jem_archive/ISS2/vol2_no1_art6.pdf PDF]</ref> Other strategies include the preservation of natural [[forest floor]] constituents and retention of woody debris and substrates. In one study concerning [[Douglas-fir]] seedlings, removal of forest floor debris and soil compaction decreased EcM fungal diversity and abundance by 60%.<ref name="onehundredone">Amaranthus, Michael P., et al. Soil compaction and organic matter affect conifer seedling nonmycorrhizal and ectomycorrhizal root tip abundance and diversity. Forest Service research paper. No. PB--97-104301/XAB; FSRP-PNW--494. Forest Service, Portland, OR (United States). Pacific Northwest Research Station, 1996. [http://www.osti.gov/energycitations/product.biblio.jsp?osti_id=406027]</ref> Another study focused on the removal of pinegrass, and found that its removal had similar reductions in diversity and richness of EcM fungi.<ref name="twentytwo" />
Some strategies, such as [[controlled burn|prescribed burns]], have complicated ramifications due to conflicting evidence. Some claim that fires have negative effects on EcM survival and diversity,<ref name="onehundredtwo">{{cite journal | last1=Dahlberg | first1=Anders | display-authors=etal | year=2001 | title=Post-fire legacy of ectomycorrhizal fungal communities in the Swedish boreal forest in relation to fire severity and logging intensity | journal=Biological Conservation | volume=100 | issue=2| pages=151–161 | doi=10.1016/s0006-3207(00)00230-5}}</ref> while other show neutral, or even positive effects.<ref name="onehundred" /><ref name="onehundredthree">{{cite journal | last1=Mah | first1=Karen | display-authors=etal | year=2001 | title=The impacts of broadcast burning after clear-cutting on the diversity of ectomycorrhizal fungi associated with hybrid spruce seedlings in central British Columbia | url=http://web.unbc.ca/forestry/Hugues/pdf%20files/The%20impacts%20of%20broadcast%20burning.pdf | journal=Canadian Journal of Forest Research | volume=31 | issue=2| pages=224–235 | doi=10.1139/x00-158}}</ref> Clearly, different organisms and different community structures will react to such burns differently. With that in mind, these diverse effects are to be expected, and research on how specific communities could respond, rather than sweeping generalizations, would be much more beneficial in the long run.
''[[Ex situ]]'' strategies for conservation of fungi are also currently under way, including ectomycorrhizal fungi, but a great deal of work is still needed. There are large culture collections maintained throughout the world; however, there are only approximately 11,500 species included. This represents only about 17% of known fungal species, and around 1% of the world’s estimated species of fungi.<ref name="onehundredfour">{{cite journal | last1=Hawksworth | first1=David L | year=1991 | title=The fungal dimension of biodiversity: magnitude, significance, and conservation | url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0953756209808101 | journal=Mycological Research | volume=95 | issue=6| pages=641–655 | doi=10.1016/S0953-7562(09)80810-1}}</ref> A great deal of worldwide cooperation is needed in order to secure the fungal genetic resource for the future.
